title: Data Generation Tutorial
text: input calls generate_AR() function.
code: R = 20 # Time series of different lengths n = c(rep(500, R/2), rep(800, R/2)) burn = 50  ## `ARp` method: tmp = gen_data(   gen_method = "ARp",   phi = c(0.5),   n = n,   R = R,   burn = burn  )  # extract time series ts = tmp$ts_list  # extract true_phi tp = tmp$true_phi  # plot the time series ## Create an empty plot  plot(    x = c(),    y = c(),    xlim = c(0, 800),    ylim = range(ts),    ylab = "",    xlab = "time",    main = "AR(0.5) of Varying Lengths"  )  for (r in 1:10) {    lines(ts[[r]][, 1], col = "blue")  }  for (r in 11:R) {    lines(ts[[r]][, 1], col = "red")  }

title: Data Generation Tutorial
code: full_spec <- matrix(data = NA, nrow = 1000, ncol = R) omega <- seq(0, pi, length.out = 1000) phi <- tp for(r in 1:R){   full_spec[,r] = arma_spec_vectorized(omega = omega, phi = phi) }  matplot(x = omega,         y = full_spec,         type = "l",         ylab = bquote(g(omega)),         xlab = bquote(omega),         lwd = 2)

title: Data Generation Tutorial
text: input calls generate_AR1vary() function.
code: R = 20 # Time series of different lengths n = c(rep(500, R/2), rep(800, R/2)) burn = 50  ## `AR1vary` method:  tmp <- gen_data(    gen_method = "AR1vary",    n = n,    R = R,    min = 0.45,    max = 0.6,    burn = burn  )  # extract time series ts = tmp$ts_list  # extract true_phi tp = tmp$true_phi  # plot the time series ## Create an empty plot  plot(    x = c(),    y = c(),    xlim = c(0, 800),    ylim = range(ts),    ylab = "",    xlab = "time",    main = "Varying AR(1) of Varying Lengths"  )  for (r in 1:10) {    lines(ts[[r]][, 1], col = "blue")  }  for (r in 11:R) {    lines(ts[[r]][, 1], col = "red")  }

title: Data Generation Tutorial
code: full_spec <- matrix(data = NA, nrow = 1000, ncol = R) omega <- seq(0, pi, length.out = 1000) phi <- tp for(r in 1:R){   full_spec[,r] = arma_spec_vectorized(omega = omega, phi = phi[r]) }  matplot(x = omega,         y = log(full_spec),         type = "l",         ylab = bquote("log("*g(omega)*")"),         xlab = bquote(omega),         lwd = 2)

title: Data Generation Tutorial
text: input calls generate_AR2_mixture() function.
code: ## `AR2mix` method:  R <- 20 # Time series of different lengths n = c(rep(500, R/2), rep(800, R/2))   peaks1 <- runif(R, min = 0.2, max = 0.23)  bandwidths1 <- runif(R, min = .1, max = .2)  peaks2 <- runif(R,                  min = (pi * (2 / 5)) - 0.1,                  max = (pi * (2 / 5)) + 0.1)  bandwidths2 <- rep(0.15, R)  peaks <- rbind(peaks1, peaks2)  bandwidths <- rbind(bandwidths1, bandwidths2)    tmp <- gen_data(    gen_method = "AR2mix",    peaks = peaks,    bandwidths = bandwidths,    n = n  )   # extract time series ts = tmp$ts_list  # extract out the phi1 phi1_true = tmp$phi1_true # extract out the phi2 phi2_true = tmp$phi2_true  # plot the time series ## Create an empty plot  plot(    x = c(),    y = c(),    xlim = c(0, 800),    ylim = range(ts),    ylab = "",    xlab = "time",    main = "Mixture AR(2) of Varying Lengths"  )  for (r in 1:10) {    lines(ts[[r]][, 1], col = "blue")  }  for (r in 11:R) {    lines(ts[[r]][, 1], col = "red")  }

what: True log Spectral Density for AR2mix
title: Data Generation Tutorial
code: full_spec <- matrix(data = NA, nrow = 1000, ncol = R) omega <- seq(0, pi, length.out = 1000)  # Calculate the SDF for generated data: for(r in 1:R){   g = rep(0, length(omega))   for(p in 1:nrow(phi1_true)){     g = g + arma_spec_vectorized(omega, phi = c(phi1_true[p,r], phi2_true[p,r]))   }   full_spec[,r] = g }  matplot(x = omega,         y = log(full_spec),         type = "l",         ylab = bquote("log("*g(omega)*")"),         xlab = bquote(omega),         lwd = 2)

title: HBEST Tutorial
text: Include section Mixture AR(2) data generated. Let us generate R=20R = 20 many conditionally independent time series. example set 80%80\% R-many time series length 600600; remaining 20%20\% length 12001200.
code: set.seed(101) R <- 20 # Create what percent will be "small" lengths sm_per <- .80 lg_per <- 1 - .80 # Create the lengths for small and large sm_length <- 600 lg_length <- 1200  n <- c(   rep(sm_length, round(sm_per * R)),   rep(lg_length, round(lg_per * R)) )  # Generate peaks and bandwidths peaks1 <- runif(R, min = 0.2, max = 0.23) bandwidths1 <- runif(R, min = .1, max = .2) peaks2 <- runif(R, min = (pi * (2 / 5)) - 0.1, max = (pi * (2 / 5)) + 0.1) bandwidths2 <- rep(0.15, R) peaks <- rbind(peaks1, peaks2) bandwidths <- rbind(bandwidths1, bandwidths2)  # Generate data from the AR2mix option. out <- gen_data(   gen_method = "AR2mix",   peaks = peaks,   bandwidths = bandwidths,   n = n )  # extract out the time-series ts_list = out$ts_list # extract out the phi1 phi1_true = out$phi1_true # extract out the phi2 phi2_true = out$phi2_true # Create storage for true SDF  full_spec = matrix(data = NA, nrow = 1000, ncol = R) # Create a dense grid of omegas to plot over full_omega = seq(0, pi, length.out = 1000)  # Calculate the SDF for generated data: for(r in 1:R){   g = rep(0, length(full_omega))   for(p in 1:nrow(phi1_true)){     g = g + arma_spec(full_omega, phi = c(phi1_true[p,r], phi2_true[p,r]))   }   full_spec[,r] = g }  # Create a blank plot plot(x = c(), y = c(), xlim = c(0, 1200), ylim = c(-25, 25), xlab = "Time", ylab = "") # Plot each of the raw generated time series for (r in 1:R) {   lines(ts_list[[r]][, 1]) } # Plot individual views par(mfrow = c(5,2), mar = c(1.75,2,2,0.2)) # plot first 5 for(r in 1:5){   plot(ts_list[[r]][,1], type = "l",        ) } # plot last 5 for(r in 16:R){   plot(ts_list[[r]][,1], type = "l",        ) }

title: HBEST Tutorial
text: section walkthrough use HBEST() function generated data ; calculate estimate(s) Œ≤rb\beta_{rb} using samples Œ≤bglob\beta^{glob}_{b} Œ≤rbloc\beta^{loc}_{rb}; calculate estimates gglob(œâ),grloc(œâ),grb(œâ)g^{glob}(\omega), g^{loc}_{r}(\omega), g_{rb}(\omega). HBEST() HBEST_fast() take arguments. Either method produce results, HBEST_fast() method slight computational improvements. arguments required run either function : ts_list list R long containing vectors stationary time series potentially different lengths. B integer specifying number basis coefficients (including intercept basis coefficient. iter integer specifying number iterations MCMC algorithm embedded function. tausquared scalar used initial value tausquared controls global smoothing effect. burnin integer specifying burn-removed end sampling algorithm. zeta_min scalar controlling smallest value Œ∂\zeta can take. , zeta_min^2 smallest value zetasquared can take. zeta_max scalar controlling largest value Œ∂\zeta can take. , zeta_max^2 largest value zetasquared can take. tau_min scalar controlling smallest value œÑ\tau can take. , tau_min^2 smallest value tausquared can take. tau_max scalar controlling largest value œÑ\tau can take. , tau_max^2 largest value tausquared can take. num_gpts scalar controlling denseness grid sampling tausquared zetasquared. nu_tau scalar indicating degrees freedom prior œÑ\tau. nu_zeta scalar indicating degrees freedom prior Œ∂\zeta. sigmasquared_glob scalar‚Ä¶ sigmasquared_loc scalar‚Ä¶ example, choose following settings hyperparameters initialization œÑ2\tau^2.
code: iter = 5000 burnin = 500 B = 15 # Set/initialize hyper-parameters: nu_tau = 2 sigmasquared_glob = 100 sigmasquared_loc = 0.1 tausquared = 10 nu_zeta = 5 # Set hyper-parameters for update on zeta and tausquared (Griddy): zeta_min = 1.001 zeta_max = 15 tau_min = 0.001 tau_max = 100 num_gpts = 1000 results <- HBEST::HBEST(   ts_list = ts_list,   B = B,   iter = iter,   sigmasquared_glob = sigmasquared_glob,   sigmasquared_loc = sigmasquared_loc,   nu_tau = nu_tau,   tausquared = tausquared,   nu_zeta = nu_zeta,   burnin = burnin,   zeta_min = zeta_min,   zeta_max = zeta_max,   tau_min = tau_min,   tau_max = tau_max,   num_gpts = num_gpts )

title: HBEST Tutorial
text: construct estimates Œ≤rb\beta_{rb} grb(œâ)g_{rb}(\omega): first three log-SDF estimates (red) true log-SDF calculated using generated data (blue).  last three log-SDF estimates (red) true log-SDF calculated using generated data (blue). code similar code previous section.
code: # Construct an omega and Psi that is used for plotting. full_Psi =  outer(X = full_omega, Y = 0:B, FUN = function(x,y){sqrt(2)* cos(y * x)}) # Redefine the first column of full_Psi full_Psi[,1] = 1  # Create storage beta_array = array(data = NA, dim = c(iter-burnin, B+1, R)) mean_sdf = array(NA, c(length(full_omega),R)) mean_logsdf = array(NA, c(length(full_omega),R))  # Extract out the loc and glob samples glob_samps = results$glob_samps loc_samps = results$loc_samps  for(r in 1:R){ # Calculate beta from loc and glob beta_array[,,r] = loc_samps[,,r] + glob_samps # Calculate the estimate of the SDF est_sdf = (full_Psi %*% t(beta_array[,,r])) # Calculate posterior mean estimates of the SDF mean_sdf[,r] = rowMeans(exp(est_sdf)) # Calculate posterior mean estimates of the log-SDF mean_logsdf[,r] = rowMeans(est_sdf) } par(mfrow = c(1,3), bg = "white", mar = c(3.5,3.5,1,1))   for(r in 1:3){     # plot the true log-SDF     plot(x= full_omega,          y = log(full_spec[,r]),          col = "dodgerblue",          lwd = 2,          ylab = "",          xlab = "",          type = "l",          lty = 1,          ylim = c(-1.5,6.25))     # Plot the estimated log-SDF     lines(x = full_omega,          y = rowMeans((tcrossprod(full_Psi,beta_array[,,r]))),          col = "red",          lwd = 2,          ylab = "",          xlab = "",          type = "l",          lty = 1)     legend("topright", legend = c(bquote("HBEST: "*hat(g)(omega)), bquote("True: "*g(omega))),            col = c("red", "dodgerblue"),            lwd = 2)     mtext(side = 1,           text = bquote(omega),           line = 2.5,           cex = 1.2)     mtext(side = 2,           text = bquote(g(omega)),           line = 2,           cex = 1.2)    }

what: Calculate Estimates of the global log-SDF components
title: HBEST Tutorial
code: par(mfrow = c(1,1), bg = "white", mar = c(4,4,.5,.5)) # Create empty plot   plot(x = c(), y = c(),           ylim = c(-2,6.25),           xlim = c(0,pi),           main = "",           ylab = "",           xlab = "",           las = 1)   mtext(side = 2,         text = bquote(hat(g)*"("*omega*")"),         line = 2.25,         cex = 1.2)   mtext(side = 1,         text = bquote(omega),         line = 2.5,         cex = 1.2)   text(x = 0, y = par("usr")[4]-0.1*diff(par("usr")[3:4]),        labels = "", pos = 4, cex = 1.5)      matlines(x = full_omega,         y = mean_logsdf,         col = wesanderson::wes_palette("FantasticFox1")[3],         lty = 1,         lwd = 2)   lines(x = full_omega,         y = rowMeans(tcrossprod(full_Psi, glob_samps)),         col = wesanderson::wes_palette("FantasticFox1")[5],         lwd = 3)   # point-wise credible interval of global log-SDF component   lines(x = full_omega,         y = apply(tcrossprod(full_Psi, glob_samps),                   1,                   FUN = function(x){quantile(x, 0.025)}),         col = "black",         lwd = 1,         lty = 2)   lines(x = full_omega,         y = apply(tcrossprod(full_Psi, glob_samps),                   1,                   FUN = function(x){quantile(x, 0.975)}),         col = "black",         lwd = 1,         lty = 2)    legend("topright",          legend = c(bquote(hat(g)*"("*omega*")"),                     bquote(hat(g)^"glob"*"("*omega*")"), "95% C.I."),          col = c(wesanderson::wes_palette("FantasticFox1")[3],                  wesanderson::wes_palette("FantasticFox1")[5],                  "black"),          lty = c(1,1,2),          bg = "white",          lwd = 2,          bty = "n")

what: Posterior mean (over iterations) of local log-SDF components
title: HBEST Tutorial
text: simplicity notation, iith iteration estimate: ùõÉrloc\pmb{\beta}^{loc}_{r} written ùêûi(r)\pmb{e}_{}^{(r)} sections follow $$ h_i^{(r)}(\omega) = \pmb{\psi}(\omega)^T \pmb{e}_i^{(r)}\\ $$ $$ \bar{h}^{(r)}(\omega)= \frac{1}{} \sum_{=1}^{} h_i^{(r)}(\omega) = \frac{1}{} \sum_{=1}^{} \pmb{\psi}(\omega)^T \pmb{e}_i^{(r)} = \pmb{\psi}(\omega)^T  \left(\frac{1}{} \sum_{=1}^{} \pmb{e}_i^{(r)}\right) = \pmb{\psi}(\omega)^T \bar{\pmb{e}}^{(r)}\\ $$
code: # calculate beta^local from beta and glob # create object to store beta^local values: loc_array = array(NA, dim(beta_array)) # Create storage for the standard deviation calculation: sd_loc = array(NA, c(length(full_omega),  R))  for(r in 1:R){   loc_array[,,r] = beta_array[,,r] - glob_samps   # calculate the estimated local component   sd_loc[,r] = apply(tcrossprod(full_Psi, loc_array[,,r]), 1, sd)  } # Calculate the spectral density only using beta^loc_{rb} par(mfrow = c(1,1), bg = "white", mar = c(4,4,.5,.5))   plot(x = c(), y = c(),           ylim = c(-0.5,0.5),           xlim = c(0,pi),           main = "",           ylab = "",           xlab = "",           las = 1)   mtext(side = 2,         text = bquote(hat(g)^(loc)*"("*omega*")"),         line = 2.25,         cex = 1.2)   mtext(side = 1,         text = bquote(omega),         line = 2.5,         cex = 1.2)   matlines(x = full_omega,         y = full_Psi %*% apply(loc_array, c(2,3), mean),         col = wesanderson::wes_palette("FantasticFox1")[5],         lwd = 1)

text: $$ h_i^{(r)}(\omega) = \pmb{\psi}(\omega)^T \pmb{e}_i^{(r)}\\ $$ $$ \bar{h}^{(r)}(\omega)= \frac{1}{} \sum_{=1}^{} h_i^{(r)}(\omega) = \frac{1}{} \sum_{=1}^{} \pmb{\psi}(\omega)^T \pmb{e}_i^{(r)} = \pmb{\psi}(\omega)^T  \left(\frac{1}{} \sum_{=1}^{} \pmb{e}_i^{(r)}\right) = \pmb{\psi}(\omega)^T \bar{\pmb{e}}^{(r)}\\ $$ h‚Äæ‚Äæ(œâ)=1R‚àër=1Rh‚Äæ(r)(œâ) \bar{\bar{h}}(\omega) = \frac{1}{R}\sum_{r=1}^{R} \bar{h}^{(r)}(\omega) Sample standard deviation replicates ùìàÃÇrep(œâ)=1R‚àí1‚àër=1R(h‚Äæ(r)(œâ)‚àíh‚Äæ‚Äæ(œâ))2 \widehat{\mathcal{s}}_{\text{rep}}(\omega) = \sqrt{\frac{1}{R-1} \sum_{r = 1}^{R} \left( \bar{h}^{(r)}(\omega) - \bar{\bar{h}}(\omega)\right)^2}
code: par(mfrow = c(1,1), bg = "white", mar = c(4,5,.5,.5))   plot(x = c(), y = c(),           ylim = c(0,0.2),           xlim = c(0,pi),           main = "",           ylab = "",           xlab = "",           las = 1)   mtext(side = 2,         text = bquote("SD("*hat(g)[r]^"loc"*"("*omega*"))"),         line = 3,         cex = 1.2)   mtext(side = 1,         text = bquote(omega),         line = 2.5,         cex = 1.2)      matlines(x = full_omega,            y = apply((full_Psi %*% apply(loc_array, c(2,3), mean)),                      1,                      sd),         col = wesanderson::wes_palette("FantasticFox1")[5],         lwd = 2)

text: Sample standard deviation iterations. $$ h^{(r)}(\omega) = \pmb{\psi}(\omega)^T \pmb{e}^{(r)}\\ $$ $$ \text{Var}(h^{(r)}(\omega)\mid -) = \text{Var}(\pmb{\psi}(\omega)^T \pmb{e}^{(r)} \mid -)\\ $$ $$ S^{(r)}(\omega) = \sqrt{\text{Var}(h^{(r)}(\omega)\mid -)}\\ $$ SÃÇ(r)(œâ)=1/(‚àí1)‚àë=1I(hi(r)(œâ)‚àíh‚Äæ(r)(œâ))2 \widehat{S}^{(r)}(\omega) = \sqrt{1/(-1) \sum_{= 1}^{} ( h_i^{(r)}(\omega) - \bar{h}^{(r)}(\omega))^2}

what: Average L2 norm of local log-SDF component
title: HBEST Tutorial
text: iteration calculating L2 norm Œ≤rloc\beta^{loc}_r piece . Li(r)=12œÄ‚à´02œÄ(ùõô(œâ)Tùêûi(r))2dœâ L_i^{(r)} = \sqrt{\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{0}^{2\pi} (\pmb{\psi}(\omega)^T \pmb{e}_i^{(r)})^2 d\omega}
code: g_hat2 = function(omega, e){   # omega is a single omega to evaluate over   # b is a vector of b's   # create psi:   psi = outer(X = omega, Y = 0:(length(e)-1), FUN = function(x,y){sqrt(2)* cos(y * x)})   psi[,1] = 1   # calculate f(\omega):   g = (psi %*% e)^2   return(g) }  locnorm_hat = apply(loc_array , c(1,3), FUN = function(e){integrate(g_hat2, lower = 0, upper = 2*pi, e = e)$value / (2*pi)}) library(ggplot2) #> Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.5.2  df = data.frame("L" = c(sqrt(locnorm_hat))) ggplot2::ggplot(data = df, aes(y = L))+    ggplot2::geom_boxplot()+   ggplot2::ylab(bquote(L[i]^r))

code: HBEST(   ts_list,   B,   iter,   burnin,   sigmasquared_glob = 100,   sigmasquared_loc = 0.1,   nu_tau = 2,   tausquared = 10,   nu_zeta = 5,   zeta_min = 1.001,   zeta_max = 15,   tau_min = 0.001,   tau_max = 100,   num_gpts = 1000 )

title: A sampling algorithm for HBEST ‚Äî HBEST
text: ts_list list R long containing vectors stationary time series potentially different lengths. B integer specifying number basis coefficients (including intercept basis coefficient \(\beta_0\)). iter integer specifying number iterations MCMC algorithm embedded function. burnin integer specifying burn-removed end sampling algorithm. sigmasquared_glob scalar specifying variance prior (N(0,sigmasquared_glob)) intercept term \(\beta^{glob}_0\). (default 100 ensure diffuse prior). sigmasquared_loc scalar specifying variance prior (N(0,sigmasquared_loc)) intercept term \(\beta^{loc}_0\). (default 0.1). nu_tau scalar indicating degrees freedom prior \(\tau\). (default 2). tausquared scalar used initial value tausquared controls global smoothing effect. (default 10). nu_zeta scalar indicating degrees freedom prior \(\zeta\). (default 5). zeta_min scalar controlling smallest value \(\zeta\) can take. , zeta_min^2 smallest value zetasquared can take. (default 1.001). zeta_max scalar controlling largest value \(\zeta\) can take. , zeta_max^2 largest value zetasquared can take. (default 15). tau_min scalar controlling smallest value \(\tau\) can take. , tau_min^2 smallest value tausquared can take. (default 0.001). tau_max scalar controlling largest value \(\tau\) can take. , tau_max^2 largest value tausquared can take. (default 100). num_gpts scalar controlling denseness grid sampling tausquared zetasquared. (default 1000).

what: Time-series data generation wrapper function ‚Äî gen_data
title: Time-series data generation wrapper function ‚Äî gen_data
text: data_gen() wrapper function various time-series data generation methods. used call one six methods generates data structure required simulations HBEST() HBEST_fast().

title: Time-series data generation wrapper function ‚Äî gen_data
code: gen_data(gen_method, ...)

title: Time-series data generation wrapper function ‚Äî gen_data
text: gen_method Method data generation use. Options include ARp, AR1vary, AR2mix, MA4, MA4vary, MA4varyType2. ... arguments, passed chosen method. See details .

title: Time-series data generation wrapper function ‚Äî gen_data
text: returns appropriate objects based method chosen. See help pages function details.

title: Time-series data generation wrapper function ‚Äî gen_data
text: Available data generation methods include:

title: Time-series data generation wrapper function ‚Äî gen_data
code: ## Other examples can be found in the vignette `Data_generation_tutorial` R <- 20 n <- rep(500, R) burn <- 50  ## `ARp` method: ts <- gen_data(   gen_method = "ARp",   phi = c(0.5),   n = n,   R = R,   burn = burn )  ## `AR1vary` method: ts <- gen_data(   gen_method = "AR1vary",   n = n,   R = 5,   min = 0.45,   max = 0.6,   burn = burn )  ## `AR2mix` method: R <- 20 n <- c(rep(300, 10),        rep(800, 10)   ) peaks1 <- runif(R, min = 0.2, max = 0.23) bandwidths1 <- runif(R, min = .1, max = .2) peaks2 <- runif(R,                 min = (pi * (2 / 5)) - 0.1,                 max = (pi * (2 / 5)) + 0.1) bandwidths2 <- rep(0.15, R) peaks <- rbind(peaks1, peaks2) bandwidths <- rbind(bandwidths1, bandwidths2) ts <- gen_data(   gen_method = "AR2mix",   peaks = peaks,   bandwidths = bandwidths,   n = n )  ## `MA4` method: n <- rep(500, R) ts <- gen_data(   gen_method = "MA4",   n = n,   R = R,   burn = burn )  ## `MA4vary` method: n <- rep(500, R) alpha <- 0.05 ts <- gen_data(   gen_method = "MA4vary",   n = n,   R = R,   burn = burn,   alpha = alpha )  ## `MA4varyType2` method: n <- rep(500, R) ts <- gen_data(   gen_method = "MA4varyType2",   n = n,   R = R,   burn = burn,   alpha = alpha )

what: Generate R-many conditionally independent time series from the same AR(p) process ‚Äî generate_AR
title: Generate R-many conditionally independent time series from the same AR(p) process ‚Äî generate_AR
text: generate_AR() generates R-many conditionally independent time series AR(p) process using arima.sim().

title: Generate R-many conditionally independent time series from the same AR(p) process ‚Äî generate_AR
code: generate_AR(phi, n, R = 1, burn = 50)

title: Generate R-many conditionally independent time series from the same AR(p) process ‚Äî generate_AR
text: phi vector containing AR(p) coefficients. syntax used arima.sim(), e.g. c(ar1coefficient, ar2coefficient). n numeric vector determines length time series generated. Must contain R-many entries. Time series may different lengths. R optional numeric scalar (default 1) determines many time series generate. time series stored column wise output. burn optional numeric scalar (default 50) determines n.start argument arima.sim() function.

title: Generate R-many conditionally independent time series from the same AR(p) process ‚Äî generate_AR
text: list object contains R-long list object ts_list containing matrix dimension (n[r] x 1) true_phi user-specified phi.

title: Generate R-many conditionally independent time series from the same AR(p) process ‚Äî generate_AR
code: ## An AR(1) process with `phi = 0.5` and different length time-series phi <- c(0.5) R <- 5 n <- c(rep(2000, R - 2), rep(1000, R - 3)) burn <- 100 ts <- generate_AR(   phi = c(0.5),   n = n,   R = R,   burn = 100 )$ts_list ## `$ts_list` output generates an R-long list that each ## contains an (n[r] x 1) matrix  ## Plot ## Create an empty plot plot(   x = c(),   y = c(),   xlim = c(0, 2000),   ylim = range(ts),   ylab = "",   xlab = "time" ) for (r in 1:3) {   lines(ts[[r]][, 1], col = "blue") } for (r in 4:R) {   lines(ts[[r]][, 1], col = "red") }   #' ## An AR(1) process with `phi = 0.5` and same length time-series phi <- c(0.5) R <- 5 n <- rep(2000, R) burn <- 100 ts <- generate_AR(   phi = c(0.5),   n = n,   R = R,   burn = 100 )$ts_list ## `$ts_list` output generates an R-long list that each ## contains an (n[r] x 1) matrix  ## Plot ## Create an empty plot plot(   x = c(),   y = c(),   xlim = c(0, 2000),   ylim = range(ts),   ylab = "",   xlab = "time" ) for (r in 1:R) {   lines(ts[[r]][, 1], col = "blue") }

code: generate_AR1_vary(n, R = 1, min = 0.45, max = 0.6, burn = 50)

title: Generate R-many conditionally independent AR(1) varying time series ‚Äî generate_AR1_vary
text: n numeric vector determines length time series generated. Must contain R-many entries. Time series may different lengths. R optional numeric scalar (default 1) determines many time series generate. time series stored column-vector list output. min optional numeric scalar (default 0.45) determines minimum value AR(1) coefficient possibly take. max optional numeric scalar (default 0.60) determines maximum value AR(1) coefficient possibly take. burn optional numeric scalar (default 50) determines n.start argument arima.sim() function.

title: Generate R-many conditionally independent AR(1) varying time series ‚Äî generate_AR1_vary
text: list object contains following fields:

title: Generate R-many conditionally independent AR(1) varying time series ‚Äî generate_AR1_vary
code: ## An AR(1) process with coefficient(s) selected from $U(min,max)$ ## with different length time-series R <- 5 n <- c(rep(2000, R - 2), rep(1000, R - 3)) burn <- 100 ts <- generate_AR1_vary(   n = n,   R = 5 )$ts_list ## `$ts_list` output generates an R-long list that each ## contains an (n[r] x 1) matrix  ## Plot ## Create an empty plot plot(   x = c(),   y = c(),   xlim = c(0, 2000),   ylim = range(ts),   ylab = "",   xlab = "time" ) for (r in 1:3) {   lines(ts[[r]][, 1], col = "blue") } for (r in 4:R) {   lines(ts[[r]][, 1], col = "red") }   ## An AR(1) process with coefficient(s) selected from $U(min,max)$ ## with same length time-series phi <- c(0.5) R <- 5 n <- rep(2000, R) burn <- 100 ts <- generate_AR1_vary(   n = n,   R = 5 )$ts_list ## `$ts_list` output generates an R-long list that each ## contains an (n[r] x 1) matrix  ## Plot ## Create an empty plot plot(   x = c(),   y = c(),   xlim = c(0, 2000),   ylim = range(ts),   ylab = "",   xlab = "time" ) for (r in 1:R) {   lines(ts[[r]][, 1], col = "blue") }    ## Output is a list containing a (1000 x 5) matrix and a 5 long vector ## containing the true phi values randomly generated to create the ## R many time series.

title: Generate R-many conditionally independent varying AR(2) time series with angle representation ‚Äî generate_AR2_mixture
text: list object contains following fields:

title: Generate R-many conditionally independent varying AR(2) time series with angle representation ‚Äî generate_AR2_mixture
code: R = 20 n = c(rep(300, R/2), rep(800, R/2))  ## Generate peaks and bandwidths: peaks1 = stats::runif(R,                       min = 0.2,                       max = 0.23) bandwidths1 = stats::runif(R,                            min = .1,                            max = .2) peaks2 = stats::runif(R,                       min = (pi * (2/5)) - 0.1,                       max = (pi * (2/5)) + 0.1) bandwidths2 = rep(0.15,                   R) peaks = rbind(peaks1, peaks2) bandwidths = rbind(bandwidths1, bandwidths2)  ## Call the function to generate time series ts = generate_AR2_mixture(peaks = peaks,  bandwidths = bandwidths,  n = n)$ts_list  ## `$ts_list` returns an R-long list object each with a (n_vary[r] x 1) matrix object, ## `$phi1_true` returns a (1 x 20) matrix of the first AR(2) ## coefficients, and `$phi2_true` returns a ## (1 x 20) matrix object of the second AR(2) coefficients.  ## Plot ## Create an empty plot plot(   x = c(),   y = c(),   xlim = c(0, 800),   ylim = range(ts),   ylab = "",   xlab = "time" ) for (r in 1:10) {   lines(ts[[r]][, 1], col = "blue") } for (r in 11:R) {   lines(ts[[r]][, 1], col = "red") }

title: Generate R-many conditionally independent MA(4) time series ‚Äî generate_MA4

title: Generate R-many conditionally independent MA(4) time series ‚Äî generate_MA4
code: R <- 20 ## For time series of different lengths: n <- c(rep(500, R / 2), rep(800, R / 2)) burn <- 50 ts <- generate_MA4(n = n, R = R, burn = burn)$ts_list  ## Returns an R-long list object each with a (500 x 1) matrix object, ## and a (4 x 20) matrix of true MA(4) coefficients - all the same value.  ## Plot ## Create an empty plot plot(   x = c(),   y = c(),   xlim = c(0, 800),   ylim = range(ts),   ylab = "",   xlab = "time" ) for (r in 1:10) {   lines(ts[[r]][, 1], col = "blue") } for (r in 11:R) {   lines(ts[[r]][, 1], col = "red") }

what: generate R-many conditionally independent varying MA(4) time series ‚Äî generate_MA4_vary
title: generate R-many conditionally independent varying MA(4) time series ‚Äî generate_MA4_vary
text: generate_MA4_vary() generates R-many time series MA(4) used base coefficients variation (-.3,-.6,-.3,.6). based MA(4) used Granados-Garcia et al. (2022) .

title: generate R-many conditionally independent varying MA(4) time series ‚Äî generate_MA4_vary
code: generate_MA4_vary(n, R = 1, burn = 50, alpha = 0.05)

title: generate R-many conditionally independent varying MA(4) time series ‚Äî generate_MA4_vary
text: n numeric vector determines length time series generated. Must contain R-many entries. Time series may different lengths. R optional scalar indicating number conditionally independent time series generated. (default 1). burn scalar indicating amount burn-used stats::arima.sim().  (default 50). alpha scalar specifying variation wanted base coefficients. (default 0.05).

title: generate R-many conditionally independent varying MA(4) time series ‚Äî generate_MA4_vary
text: function returns list containing:

title: generate R-many conditionally independent varying MA(4) time series ‚Äî generate_MA4_vary
text: variation around base theta coefficients generated function : Sample 4 values \(N(0,1)\) use "mean". Calculate: basetheta + alpha * mu_r * abs(basetheta) basetheta original coefficients; mu_r 4 sampled values \(N(0,1)\); alpha user-specified scalar controls variation around base coefficients. Generate: new time-series using new theta value step 2. Repeat steps 1-3 R-many times.

title: generate R-many conditionally independent varying MA(4) time series ‚Äî generate_MA4_vary
code: R <- 20 ## For time series of different lengths: n <- c(rep(500, R/2), rep(800, R/2)) burn <- 50 alpha <- 0.05 ts <- generate_MA4_vary(n = n, R = R, burn = burn, alpha = alpha)$ts_list  ## The function returns an R-long list object each with a (n[r] x 1) matrix object, ## a (4 x 20) matrix of true MA(4) coefficients, ## a scalar returning the alpha provided, ## and a (4 x 20) matrix of the standard normal values generated for each R.  ## Plot ## Create an empty plot plot(   x = c(),   y = c(),   xlim = c(0, 800),   ylim = range(ts),   ylab = "",   xlab = "time" ) for (r in 1:10) {   lines(ts[[r]][, 1], col = "blue") } for (r in 11:R) {   lines(ts[[r]][, 1], col = "red") }

text: generate_MA4_varyType2() generates R-many time series MA(4) used base coefficients variation (-.3,-.6,-.3,.6). version data generation, first coefficient changed, coefficients left . based MA(4) used Granados-Garcia et al. (2022) . data generation used Lee et al. (2025) .

title: Generate Conditionally Independent R-Many MA(4) Varying Time Series of the Same Length (Version 2) ‚Äî generate_MA4_varyType2
code: generate_MA4_varyType2(n, R = 1, burn = 50, alpha = 0.05)

title: Generate Conditionally Independent R-Many MA(4) Varying Time Series of the Same Length (Version 2) ‚Äî generate_MA4_varyType2
text: n numeric vector determines length time series generated. Must contain R-many entries. Time series may different lengths. R optional scalar indicating number conditionally independent time series generated. (default 1). burn optional scalar indicating amount burn-used stats::arima.sim().  (default 50). alpha optional scalar specifying variation wanted first base coefficient. (default 0.05).

title: Generate Conditionally Independent R-Many MA(4) Varying Time Series of the Same Length (Version 2) ‚Äî generate_MA4_varyType2
text: function returns list containing:

title: Generate Conditionally Independent R-Many MA(4) Varying Time Series of the Same Length (Version 2) ‚Äî generate_MA4_varyType2
text: variation around first base theta coefficient generated : Sample 1 value \(N(0,1)\) use "mean". Calculate: basetheta[1] + alpha * mu_r * abs(basetheta[1]) basetheta[1] original first MA(4) coefficient; mu_r 1 sampled values \(N(0,1)\); alpha user-specified scalar controls variation around first base coefficient. Generate: new time-series using new theta value step 2. Repeat steps 1-3 R-many times.

title: Generate Conditionally Independent R-Many MA(4) Varying Time Series of the Same Length (Version 2) ‚Äî generate_MA4_varyType2
code: R <- 20 ## For time series of different lengths: n <- c(rep(500, R / 2), rep(800, R / 2)) burn <- 50 alpha <- 0.05 ts <- generate_MA4_varyType2(n = n, R = R, burn = burn, alpha = alpha)$ts_list  # plot the time series generated: # create an empty plot plot(   x = c(), y = c(),   xlim = c(0, 800),   ylim = range(ts),   main = "Example",   ylab = "",   xlab = "time" ) for (r in 1:10) {   lines(ts[[r]][, 1], col = "blue") } for (r in 11:R) {   lines(ts[[r]][, 1], col = "red") }   ## Returns an R-long list object each with a (500 x 1) matrix object, ## a (4 x 20) matrix of true MA(4) coefficients, ## a scalar returning the alpha provided, ## and a (4 x 20) matrix of the standard normal values generated for each R.
